message: just interested if there is a standard or norm.

Personally I am of the view that the the non-technical founder should take and equal percentage of the equity up until you start to develop and invest time into your concept - from that point on you have to negotiate equity based on what you all bring to the table i.e. money, technical expertise, contacts, etc...
the right number would be as much as either party think it's a fair share no?
okay @alastairC good point
impossible question to answer - it depends on what value you think the non-technical founder brought to the creation and development of the idea/concept.
imo best to have a technical team, build product and then outsource legal/sales/marketing
this isn't that kind of project, if it has no partners then it can't launch. But fair enough with most consumer apps that'd be the case
I'm not saying it has no partners just saying if it didn't.

This heavily depends on the skillset of the non technical founder. @alastairC is dead on with that one. If he can bring a lot to the table with the business and marketing side of things he could be an equal partner. Execution is more than just how well you coded the product.

just come to an agreement that all founders are comfortable with but most importantly put an earn out period with a cliff of 6 months (eg 3 founders each 33% each) where no one earns anything until the first 6 months and then they earn 5.5% each 6 months therafter.

This means at the end of 3 years they have earnt their 33% each (obviously minus the dilution for any investment taken on during this 3 year period).
It depends what they bring to the table, if they bring either enough work ethic, money or ability to get money to the table there is no reason why they shouldn't get equal equity.
Let the lawyers handle the details.
@deancollins Why do you propose that instead of the typical 1/4 vesting?
http://www.andrew.cmu.edu/user/fd0n/35%20Founders'%20Pie%20Calculator.htm
This should be helpful
@jamespaxi Funny you say that. So no designer, marketing cofounders whould exist in yur opinion, right?
There is no right or wrong
There is a huge difference between a designed & engineered product and an engineered product
take Tumblr and Posterous

you can't outsource business, that way you'll only get shafted by investors and other companies
I've seen teams were one guys does literally ALL of the biz dev, would that guy deserve a bigger cut than the guy who only draws the icons? maybe
Non-tech founders deserve a cut, but the size depends of what they do
after all there have been countless teams that didnt make it because they didnt know anything about business
on the other hand I've seen startups founded only by non-tech types that go on to secure tons of funding
